channel.title: WEBer Atelier
channel.description: Bullocks, I can't get any satisfaction.#end of line

item.title: Urban Agriculture in Confined Spaces - Part I
item.description:
Urban Agriculture in Confined Spaces - Part I

At the advent of yet another spring season in the Northern Hemisphere. Sorry to all our antipodals, but it is yet another wonderful opportunity to get experimental with Greening, which is a slang jargon word for enjoying the hobby of producing decorative and or healthy plants.

In this multipart series, we will be looking over options within a limited urban environment. As time marches on and technology improves things, while still not seeing the true full ramifications of the decisions now made, it would actually be quiet a good safety net for all of us to consider growing nearly anything. I just heard a shout-out from the Rastas and others out there.

Some of the subjects that will be covered in this series are as follows:

  1. Small Space Veggie Gardens: The Perks & Ground Rules
  2. Types of Small Space Gardens
  3. Time-Saving Tips
  4. How to Grow the More Popular Veggies

Now, we could possibly go into growing tomatoes, but in all likelihood, this narrator will not traverse that path due to his own aversions. Having moved from a western equatorial climate with sun, heat and humidity to the Northern section of another continent did not stifle the human inclination to grow the things they love and often personally use. One year, I went all out to try and grow 30 tomato plants of varying breeds. The lack of sun, due to coastal over-cast skies and lower temperatures, I harvested 5 small red tomatoes that year, and 5 crates of green tomatoes with black mold spots marking their end. Meh, for nostalgia, perhaps we will include tomatoes.

Greening, health and perhaps mostly due to the pleasure of endowing our children with a rudimentary understanding of how to provide for themselves in an unforeseeable future gives me the satisfactory feeling accustom to being a father.

item.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
item.description:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
